name: Venous Leg Ulcer
description: The most common type of leg ulcer, caused by chronic venous hypertension leading to skin changes and eventual ulceration. Characteristically located in the gaiter area (medial malleolus region) with surrounding lipodermatosclerosis. Compression therapy is the mainstay of treatment.

pathophysiology.mechanism: Chronic venous hypertension → capillary damage → extravasation of fibrinogen and RBCs → pericapillary fibrin cuffs → tissue hypoxia → ulceration

tissue_changes.lipodermatosclerosis: Fibrosis of subcutaneous tissue, inverted champagne bottle leg

location.never: Foot or toes (think arterial if there)

ulcer_characteristics.base: Red granulation tissue (if healthy), may have slough
ulcer_characteristics.pain: Minimal to moderate, improved with elevation

diagnosis.clinical_diagnosis: Based on location, appearance, and surrounding skin changes

ankle_brachial_index.purpose: Exclude significant arterial disease before compression
ankle_brachial_index.mixed_ulcer: If ABI 0.5-0.8, use reduced compression with caution

diagnosis.biopsy: If ulcer present >3 months without healing, to exclude malignancy (Marjolin ulcer)

compression_therapy.mechanism: Reduces venous hypertension, enhances calf pump

wound_care.debridement: Sharp, enzymatic, or autolytic as needed
wound_care.infection_control: Antibiotics only for clinical infection, not colonization

management.exercise: Walking and calf exercises to enhance muscle pump

surgical_options.superficial_ablation: EVLA, RFA, or stripping of incompetent GSV/SSV

clinical_pearls: Location is key: MEDIAL malleolus = venous; LATERAL/DISTAL = think arterial
Always check ABI before applying compression - arterial disease makes compression dangerous
Compression is the MAINSTAY of treatment - without it, healing is unlikely
Chronic non-healing ulcer >3 months = biopsy to rule out squamous cell carcinoma (Marjolin)
learning_objectives: Describe the pathophysiology of venous ulcer formation
Identify the characteristic location and appearance of venous ulcers
Explain the role of compression therapy in venous ulcer management
